hey bill, I'm trying to learn a new instrumentand its not super easy to like kinda figure out a starting point of like where to start learning, and i figured since you play a ton of stuff i should ask if you kinda had any advice on how to start learning?

the magic of music all comes from right in that limbo state in between 2 choices. basically it's the space that the "no free will" nay-sayers will say shouldn't exist. but it powers all of music. just get near your instrument (or far, whatever) and just keep contemplating whether or not you should touch the instrument. change your mind. you can touch the instrument, or not, either way, but the wild ride happens as these 2 extremes battle it out within your soul
This also goes for video editing, I am not really sure what to start with. Any advice? Thanks!

start with a blank space, maybe a rectangle, as long as you're getting into the video mindset (most videos are probably rectangular). and just exercise the opportunity to possibly put 1 dot on the page, anywhere. specifically call upon your ability to place the dot at any location on the page. try to find a place where you think no one has ever put the dot before. or, try to find the place where you think is the absolute #1 most common location for the dot to possibly be placed. or, if you are feeling absolutely ridiculous, you can try to place the dot in a location that has a uniqueness level of exactly 50%

I got my first job at a studio right before the pandemic hit, and that coupled with other personal stuff really clogged me up on writing and recording. I might now be facing the prospect of having to find work elsewhere (not actually sure yet) and I'm suddenly panicking about not having used my time here wisely and how to try and actually release and share music, and I'm wondering if you have any advice you could offer on what to do?

i'm not sure what kind of studio you are talking about, but just reading between the lines it sounds like it is a pretty heavy studio with a lot of... stuff in it, stuff which maybe you don't normally have access to. and it sounds like you are getting fearful and confused about your path to production. so for this i recommend immediately turning to a production process which is much simpler. sometimes when i'm feeling overwhelmed i dig deep somewhere into the past and find a some live video of a guy in the 1970s performing a song with a guitar and his voice, on stage, in real time, in 1 take. just to remind me of how simple it can be to create a song. there are millions of ways to produce music, but from what you described it sounds like you'd be pleased to discover some ways that are much easier, quicker, and readily within reach at any hour of the day. and believe me, those ways exist and they're all around us. and then you can just work your way up from there

You ever notice how the chorus of Material Girl is a 7-bar figure, so when later in the song it repeats after 8 bars, it gives this INCREDIBLE jumpy feeling of skipping back to the best part so soon???

the main reason it sounds surprising is because the vamp guitar riff starts and gets cut short after 1 bar when it normally expresses itself in 2. you could do the chorus in 8 bars and just land on that 1 chord for bar 8 and go back around without the guitar vamp riff, and it would sound totally expected. but because the vamp riff starts and does not finish, that is what seems to give it the surprising quality

what's the story behind "i'm scared"?

i was about to go out for a walk, and then right about when i was putting my shoes on, i came up with a high figure "(i) don't wanna Die!" with "die" on beat 1 bar 1, all notes being flat 7 except the last note being the high 1, and the rhythm being like "(&)a e a1", and i was also working on the selection process right about the same time, and somehow i switched it to "i'm scared" which seemed a bit stronger, and the bassline was working its way up and back to 1 over the course of 2 bars (more similar to what it does in 'ground plane'), and it got added to the list. i also had a bridge section which didn't get used, which i think was added to the list separately. i'd preliminarily selected 81 items, including "i'm scared", "ground plane", "i'm a huge gamer most of the time", "special sandals", a vamp similar to the 'happy' section of ground plane, and a figure that would become "at the corner store". I then i narrowed it down to a list of 16, including "i'm scared", "huge gamer", the figure that would become "corner store", and the vamp that would become "i'm happy". Then i asked the computer to choose for me from amongst those 16, and it chose number 10 which was "i'm scared". Then i think the first thing i did was i changed it so the bass gets around the line in 1 bar instead of 2, because it seemed to slam harder that way. then i wrote the rest of the song according to my best songwriting procedures and practices

Is there a story behind More Than A Dream?
yes
Its one of my favorites of yours

the verse melody came to me in a dream (about a year earlier). but when i chose that one for the next song (later) i decided to "do it right" ............. it was written while cruising around google streetview. almost as if written while driving. i made no deadline and was not demanding myself to get the answers particularly quickly. in retrospect this might have been a mistake. when it came to the recording process, i also was transitioning to different software which would allow me to do my own computer programming to get more of the functioning i want. also a massive rabbit hole. when the song (audio) was finally completed, my mind was already racing with potential strategies to transform everything so i never take too long ever again. i was fantasizing about the ancient old days where people used to use 4-track machines. i was fantasizing about the old days when people used to be able to record an entire album in a day. i was obsessed with the idea of putting insanely simple limitation rules on the process, in the future. for the video i experimented with a "2 day or reset" strategy, where i'm forced to abandon the work if the video is not completed in 2 days. there were reasons why i thought this would be better than a simple deadline strategy. this evolved into a section-by-section "1 hour or reset" strategy. it was thrilling in some ways, but ridiculously exhausting in other ways. i ended up giving up on that strategy, but i still ended up finding inspiration for quickness by looking back to some of the files for "best friends with my own front door", to try to observe and analyze how quickly i was actually making the moves, in the video production. this inspired me to get into some quickness. in any case, the video was completed very quickly after i'd been stuck in the song production forever

What is a tritone
the relationship between the note C and the nearest F#. Or, between the note C# and the nearest G. or any two notes 3 whole steps apart.
and how do I substitute it?

"tri-tone substitution" would be like let's say if you have a normal song in the key of C, and you have that D7 chord, which famously contains the notes F# and C in the chord. If you lie around thinking about music for long enough you'll notice that you can play the F# and C notes in the chord, with the D bass note, and that gives you the D7 chord, but you can also put the bass on Ab instead and that gives you an Ab7 chord just the same. So a "tri-tone substitution" is when you use Ab7 instead of D7. (or A7 instead of Eb7. or Bb7 instead of E7. and so on). seems crazy but it just might work

You've mentioned that melodies have implied chords. How do I know what they are? Or what could I do to get to the point that I can?

go through about 50 of your favorite songs, and identify each chord with brute force. quickly unpause/pause (or nowadays you can edit to loop a tiny fraction of audio very quickly) and just pick it out note by note and put it together. write down all the chords to a song (in time, with bar lines, etc.)..... once you do this for about 30 or 40 songs, i think you will find that you don't have to search for the individual notes anymore. ... maybe not even pause it at all. After about 100 more songs, you probably won't even have to listen to the song, you will be able to do it from memory. after about 1000 songs, you will probably be able to hear someone singing the melody for a song you have never heard before, without hearing the chords, and figure out what the chords should be. after 10,000 songs, you should be able to play chords along with them on the first try, never having heard the song before, and have them think you already knew the song

I think the most challenging thing about telling the truth is that I can only tell the truth that I experience and that may not be the truth that someone else experiences. Like I could look at an elephant's tail through a tube and describe what I saw and someone else could look at the same elephant but be looking at the ear and describe the elephant totally differently. And so then I feel badly for even talking about what I see because I know I can't see the whole picture, but I also can only describe what I can see. And so I feel like a liar no matter how truthful I try to be. And so then I don't want to say anything. But I'm also just so infinitely curious about the elephant and the only way any of us are gonna piece it together is by sharing the parts we can see and believing in each other. But it's so hard sometimes.
art or music is sometimes just what you need for this. it never makes any literal claims of truthful accuracy, and yet, the truth will find its way through somehow, often

How do chord progressions work?

some people say chord 'progressions' because the word 'progression' is a very large word and it stalls for time. but, chords are when you play multiple notes at the exact same time on different pitches together. it has a magic quality kind of like color. you could spend a thousand lifetimes trying to explain just how or why it works, and a thousand more lifetimes just fancying up new ways to use them
Whats a minor chord?

if you have notes C, Eb, and G together, and especially if there is also a C note in a fairly low range, that is probably considered a C minor chord. The same thing could be said about G minor, with notes G, Bb, and D, with G in the bass. and so on, with any groups of notes in this same relative orientation to each other
How about major chord?

if you have notes C, E, and G together, and especially if there is also a C note in a fairly low range, that is probably considered a C major chord. The same thing could be said about G major, with notes G, B, and D, with G in the bass. and so on, with any groups of notes in this same relative orientation to each other
